snippet: People providing DNA for research have generally been assured of their privacy, but now there are signs that they can, in fact, be identified by their DNA alone, or even by the way their cells use it.
abstract: News analysis; people providing DNA for research have generally been assured of their privacy, but evidence is emerging that DNA can be used not only to identify an individual but also to learn a great deal about them; findings highlight need to examine privacy policies in world of research, particularly in light of National Institutes of Health plan to consolidate world's databases of DNA and other genetic information.
lead_paragraph: People providing DNA for research have generally been assured of their privacy, but now there are signs that they can, in fact, be identified by their DNA alone, or even by the way their cells use it.
